sessions.description: Kick off your MozFest at this interactive Science Fair. Here, you can preview many of the projects that people will be working on over the weekend. Reconnect with old acqaintences and make some new friends and this social gathering.
sessions.title: Science Fair

sessions.description: Welcome to MozFest. Mark Surman, Executive Director the Mozilla Foundation will get us started with some brief opening remarks followed by a 'How to MozFest' tutorial by Gunner.
sessions.title: Welcome and Opening Keynote

sessions.description: Hot lunch is served on the Ground Floor, Floor 4 and Floor 6.
sessions.title: Lunch

sessions.description: Ease into Day 2 with breakfast on Floor 4. There will be plenty of hot coffee, and the time is yours for writing, hacking or connecting with new friends.
sessions.title: MozFest Breakfast

sessions.description: Hot lunch is served on the Ground Floor, Floor 4 and Floor 6.
sessions.title: Lunch

sessions.description: Celebrate what we achieved together at the Demo Party! This energetic closer is a festival favourite, and a great way to see just how much we can accomplish when we come together to imagine, build and protect the open web.
sessions.title: Closing Demo Party

sessions.description: This will be run as a drop in activity over a period of time (suggest 2hours) which can be repeated through the festival to make it available and a project which can evolve.
sessions.title: The Reactor

sessions.description: Entertain people by getting them immersed in an interactive video called 'Who Is Terror' as well as inspire them to use coding and technology to enhance creative projects.
sessions.title: Interactive Video 'Who Is Terror?' | Creative Coding

sessions.description: Entertain people by getting them immersed in an interactive video called 'Who Is Terror' as well as inspire them to use coding and technology to enhance creative projects.
sessions.title: Interactive Video 'Who Is Terror?' | Creative Coding

sessions.description: Join co-hosts Amira Dhalla and Chad Sansing live from London as they talk with guests from around the world about all the learning and making going on at at the festival. Members of the Mozilla Clubs network will appear on the webcast, as well, to share their MozFest experiences throughout the network.
sessions.title: Mozfest Curriculum Workshop

sessions.description: Building on a Mozilla-sponsored challenge from the [SPARK! youth hackathon](http://spark.stab.org/), this session will teach attendees how to create and share Minecraft adventure maps that help #teachtheweb. Using in-game command blocks programmed with JSON, participants will design and create scenarios and gameplay mechanics that turn their Minecraft worlds into games that teach about Mozilla’s key values and issues such as digital inclusion, privacy, web literacy, decentralization, openness, and innovation. You can see past examples of work done for this Fight for the Open Web! challenge in [this blogpost](https://blog.webmaker.org/open-world-open-web).
sessions.title: Fight for the Open Web! Using Minecraft for Internet Activism

sessions.description:
Participants in this highly interactive workshop will play through three offline games that teach the web. These games are some of the emerging “greatest hits” from the Mozilla Foundation’s face-to-face web literacy trainings. The group will pause after each game for a brief design critique and discussion about localizing the game for participants’ home communities.
Attendees will play
- [What If The Had the Web?](https://d157rqmxrxj6ey.cloudfront.net/chadsansing/33444/#overview) - a storytelling game about finding local and personal relevance for web literacy.
- The Paper Airplane Game ([see slide 34](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1X7YahG-tvCSm8n-A794DSj-2EI6dQY20OrRqhjaEJjk/edit#slide=id.p)) (with thanks to Kylie Peppler and Rafi Santo) - a role-playing game about the advantages of working open and pursuing innovation.
- [Werewolf-in-the-Middle](https://d157rqmxrxj6ey.cloudfront.net/chadsansing/33444/#overview) - a social, hidden-information game about the importance of encryption to online privacy.
sessions.title: Offline Games for the Open Web

sessions.description: DreamYard and Parsons School of Design are rethinking what a digital portfolio can be. For three years, the Learning Portfolio Project has been using free and open tools to help young people tell their own learning stories. Learning portfolios are online, multimedia collections of young people’s work, including finished pieces, reflections on and documentation of process, research and examples of other’s work that inspires them. We are sharing the Learning Portfolio approach with as many schools and organizations as we can to hack, remix, and adapt it to their local context and demystify portfolio development for young webmakers. Join us to learn more about the Learning Portfolio approach and help us think of the tools and resources that can be shared worldwide to make portfolios possible for all young people.
sessions.title: Moving Portfolios Forward: Designing Tools and Supports to Make Portfolio Development More Accessible

sessions.description: We'll tear apart the traditional "amoral" CS curriculum for high school students, which focuses on technical skills without a consideration of the ethical dilemmas presented through the creation of those tools.  Participants will develop course offerings which will invite & entice nontraditional students (journalists, activists, artists, etc.) into the CS program. Our current working outline includes courses such as Google vs. Oracle (learning Java while developing an understanding of the open source software ecosystem), Margin of Error (exploring pattern recognition, machine learning, and artificial intelligence and how seemingly small margin of errors have real-world impact when applied to modern machine/drone warfare), Echo Breakdown (privacy, security, systems, and the internet of things),  and the Snowden Files (developing data structures, data collection, and the potential misuse of seemingly innocuous data).
sessions.title: Build an open source ethical CS program

sessions.description:
The internet has become a crucial part of everyday life, but millions of people still lack the skills and resources to access it. I want to introduce solutions for communities with low/no connectivity to learn basic web skills.
For MozFest, I propose a session to share several offline activities through which we can teach and learn Web Literacy. Since this is a participatory workshop, participants can create their own unique activities as we progress. We will discuss how much impact tools like this can have on a community and why offline learning is so important. Some examples of activities include:
1. Learning Web Mechanics with simple card sheets and markers
2. 'A Strong Wind Blows': a chair game which makes participants wonder about Web
3. A brief example of 'Web Mechanics Speed Dating'.
4. Using Slides and video captures to explain the basics of Internet (working of web browser etc).
sessions.title: Teach The Web, without the Web

sessions.description: An installation of selfies that recalls the tension between vanity and our need for privacy
sessions.title: Vanity Trumps Privacy Trumps Vanity

sessions.description: An installation of selfies that recalls the tension between vanity and our need for privacy
sessions.title: Vanity Trumps Privacy Trumps Vanity

sessions.description: We recognize that very few societal issues affecting women have been tackled. This session will focus on handing women from all over the globe that will be in the room, the opportunity to use the web to tackle some of those issues  and to come up with one or more solutions to them.
sessions.title: My Safe Space : The Woman's Tale.

sessions.description:
Do you play games? How about MAKING GAMES for a couple of hours?
In this practical workshop you will learn how to hack analog games (think Monopoly) to explore Web Literacy.
By the end, you will have a playable prototype of your new game, and a workshop idea to use in your classroom!
sessions.title: Hacking games to teach Web Literacy

sessions.description:
Nature, in Code is a tutorial on how to learn JavaScript by learning about the forces that shape our natural world (evolution, ecology, etc.).
Written at Stanford, it has now been turned into a free open online course at EPFL. All code examples are open on natureincode.com, and a book is also available.
In this session, I will show a few examples from Nature, In Code that demonstrate the power of the web to teach fundamental basic science. My goals are to convince that JavaScript and the browser are major learning tools even for areas outside of computer science, and to teach people a few examples of how they can leverage the power of the web to develop seemingly complex simulations that run in every browser using open technologies. I also have the goal to show that coding can be taught by using nature as a guiding process.
sessions.title: Nature, in Code - learning JavaScript to reason about our world in code

sessions.description: Our session will introduce Peer 2 Peer University’s experiments building tools and designing methodologies to broaden access to adults with low digital literacy. Through Learning Circles, P2PU has partnered with libraries, public parks, museums, and community colleges around the world to run online courses as in-person study groups. Meeting once a week for 6-8 weeks, Learning Circles are designed to support digital literacy and academic mindsets, in addition to learning course content. We’ve found this work to be remarkably successful in both engaging new audiences for online learning and for invigorating community spaces as informal learning hubs. The primary goal of the workshop will to share our tools and brainstorm new ideas/interventions that can extend the potential of online learning to new audiences.
sessions.title: P2PU - Online learning face to face

sessions.description:
This session will focus on Mozilla Clubs and it’s growing network of global community members.
Mozilla Clubs are a unique and personal way to teach the Web in local communities. They are made up of technologists, thinkers and builders working together to keep the Internet alive and accessible, so people worldwide can be informed contributors and creators of the digital world.
Session participants will get an introduction to club structure, curriculum, community, partnerships, outcomes and goals. They will participate in a 30 minute hands-on activity to explore the club model in small groups so they may learn how to apply it in their local environments.
By the end of the session participants will have a basic understanding of the Mozilla Clubs model, it’s relationship to the larger Mozilla mission and how they and/or their communities can get involved.
sessions.title: Mozilla Clubs: A local, interest-based model for learning

sessions.description: How do we ensure that those that are already disconnected don't all farther behind as technology and internet advance? Teaching Community Technology offers an exclusive look at The Detroit Community Technology Project's new handbook that shares community rooted teaching methods, making technology education more and relevant. This 100+  page handbook will take you through the history of popular education while offering a step by step guide in developing community rooted technology workshops and curricula. In this session each participant will recive this limited addtion hand book, and use it to create a short workshop e community technology and popular education methods. If you are conserned about the digital divide, get excited by idea of sharing your knowledge and skills with non-techies and want to learn or refine your teaching skills, this session is for you!
sessions.title: Teaching Community Technology

sessions.description:
Technology is changing everything - the way we work, govern, communicate and educate, yet too few students are exposed to the foundational concepts behind technology or get hands-on experience creating tech. The capacity, tools and resources needed by every school to integrate CS concepts are limited.
 
Kim Wilkens & Zach Minster will share their story of integrating CS across the K-12 curriculum at St. Anne’s-Belfield School where being part of the Mozilla Learning Network has been critical to their success. Ann Marie Carrothers will share her story of creating Coding Core, an open-source lesson plan tool that empowers schools to implement CS coursework that goes beyond the #hourofcode while being easily understood by teachers and parents with no tech or CS background.
 
During this session, we are especially interested in learning from other educators, students and parents about their experience of CS - the good, the bad & the ugly, so we can brainstorm steps that can help us all bridge this critical gap in education.
sessions.title: Computer science meets the classroom

sessions.description: The open leadership camp is a new type of executive (un)education developed by the MIT Media Lab and Mozilla. It will help senior leaders in the public sector and civil society bring open strategies and technologies into their organizations. We are planning a first face-to-face camp in early 2017, and will also develop an online version. All of the curriculum will be openly available and (hopefully) useful for many other groups as well. In this session, we want to talk about the syllabus, discuss different formats for bringing the course online, and explore other strategies to propagate and reach more people.
sessions.title: Open Leadership Camp - Planning workshop

sessions.description:
In this session, we will introduce participants to the concepts and technologies behind making multiplayer games on the the web. Participants will make and play their own version of a multiplayer version of the game "Snake".
This session aims to improve participants' web literacy in the areas of coding and connecting and to decentralize control over who gets to create multi-player and multi-user experiences online
sessions.title: Multiplayer Web Games: Build your own!

sessions.description:
What’s the benefit in using the web for learning? Is it just another new “thing” that educators need to teach and students need to learn. Participants will get an introduction to the web literacy map and why web literacy matters as a foundational skill for learning. 
The session will be interactive and ask participants to crowdsource their own knowledge of the web and tag corresponding resources to the web literacy map. For example, a participant would review the skill "participate," and brainstorm a resource like Mozilla's Etherpad, which could correspond with the skills "participate" and "share." These resources will be compiled and shared out.

1.affiliated org: Hive Chicago Fund for Connected Learning
1.name: Sana Jafri

sessions.title: Learning in a connected world: Why web literacy, why now?

sessions.description:
This activity will teach teens or whomever else may be interested  how to code using our 3D light cubes such as these: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6mXM-oGggrM
We aim to inspire coding beginners into the world of programming by making programming exciting, sparking their imagination and keeping them engaged.
People will learn the fundamentals of coding by addressing our programmable light cubes and controlling them to produce various animations.
Ever since the rise of the internet and the early dot com boom, the web has slowly risen to the centre piece in connecting the civilised world. As programming is at the core of understanding how the web works and contributing to its ubiquity, I strongly believe that learning coding skills is no longer just a "good to have", it is a necessity. Hacking light will start participants on this journey!
sessions.title: Hacking Light

sessions.description: The participants will be able to access new information about being responsible in using the internet and interacting with their fellow internet citizens. Discussing this session will allow people to be more aware of the potential dangers faced by internet users. It is therefore vital to have an enough knowledge of responsible internet use by discussing it and doing some different kind of activities through role play and stuffs to protect internet users from the dangers of the Internet. This forum aims to raise awareness to dangers like cyber-bullying and fraudulent activities encountered in the everyday use of the web. This will aid the participants in making the right choices in the future and enable them to become more sensitive.
sessions.title: Reponsible Use of Internet and Ethics

sessions.description: Today’s learners should be active participants,  whose beliefs, creativity, curiosity, and self interests are at the forefront and are seen as vital attributes in the learning process. Today’s learners require engagement in the process that invokes a sense of importance and understanding. Web literacy skills are foundational to learning, like reading and mathematics, and to get the true benefit of all these skills require the learner to apply them to what is personally important.  During Fab Lab, teachers and students become facilitators, students guide their learning; questioning and challenging ideas, documenting and communicating the experience are the true indicators of what learning has occurred.  Our experiences reflect Mozilla’s web literacy map and continues to grow in that direction as we offer more opportunities and as our understanding continues to evolve regarding what tomorrow requires of global citizens.
sessions.title: FAB Lab - Teaching web literacy skills through student choice

sessions.description: This session will demystify the process of contributing to open source by guiding participants through selecting a project, getting it running locally, fixing an issue, and submitting a pull request. For many developers, particularly those just starting out or who come from an underrepresented background, contributing to open source can seem an opaque and risky process. This session will show them that it is possible for people of all skill levels to make meaningful contributions to real projects.
sessions.title: First Time Open Source Contributor Workshop

sessions.description:
This session will explore possibilities in using web literacy as a tool to welcome newcomers and/or refugees to a new city/country and to integrate themselves, drawing on our experience working with Syrian newcomer/refugee youth in Waterloo Region.
We will share some of the goals and work accomplished thus far in a pilot project we are running this fall to teach digital and web literacy skills to youth in the Syrian newcomer community, and work together with participants to build a set of learning content that takes into account the needs of newcomers, that could be used in further expansion of the project and/or in other cities and countries.
sessions.title: <Open Hearts> <Open Hands> <Open Web>

sessions.description: Overview of #a11yhacks - Accessibility Dojo's for the Visually Impaired
sessions.title: #a11yhacks -  Accessibilty Dojo's

sessions.description:
The overall goal of the session is to educate users about online identities, tracking and related tools. We will also conduct a study with attendees trialing the Firefox Containers feature to manage their online identities and gain user feedback on the prototype.
Participants will:
* Gain a basic understanding for how websites keep track of users
* Understand how identity impacts their browsing experience
* Learn what steps they can take as a user to keep identities separate
* Experiment with the new Firefox Containers feature to browse the web with different identities
Mozilla will gain:
* a better understanding of how people approach identity on the web
* valuable feedback for the design of the containers feature
sessions.title: Who does the web think you are? Masking your identity on the web.

sessions.description:
We all use the web daily, but what can we think back to a time where it was all new to us, what confused us, what still confuses us? What if you added the challenge of low literacy into the mix? This is an issue for the millions of people around the world who have yet to experience the Internet revolution first hand and often face multiple barriers to inclusion.
How can we lower the barriers for people coming online for the first time by using design to make interfaces intuitive without having to understand the jargon? Can thinking about the way we design for this audience make a better and more accessible web for everyone?
sessions.title: The challenges of building the web for non digital natives

sessions.description: This session introduces the possibilities of modern web applications and how to create your own. With recent browsers on desktop and mobile, the web now fulfils the kind of experiences that people expect and desire from apps, such as homescreen icons and even push notifications. Best of all, people can just visit a URL and have an app that works offline. If you have a basic knowledge of HTML, CSS and some JavaScript, we will help you with the rest, so you can push your websites and web apps to the next level.
sessions.title: What’s a “Progressive Web App” and How Do I Make One?

sessions.description:
* The session will teach attendees about the privacy principle Encryption: “Communication over a network, unless strongly encrypted, is never just between two parties”.
* The attendees will learn how intermediary devices, and the services that provide them, are involved in transmitting information from point A to point B on the Internet.
* The attendees will learn about Encryption through a group activity and will be able to understand its importance.
sessions.title: Let's Encrypt - Someone could listen

sessions.description: Crowd2Map Tanzania is a crowdsourced mapping project that was born a year ago at MozFest! We set out to map the blank canvas of Tanzania using mobile apps (for locals on the ground), open data (of schools&medical facilities) and satellite mapping on OpenStreetMap (for volunteers around the world). The project has since seen major successes, including thousands of schools mapped, hundreds of objects&villages that were only known to locals identified etc. Currently, we are rushing to map the region of Mara, where female genital mutilation (FGM) is prevalent, before the cutting season starts in December. Mugumu Safe House is already using our maps to "reach places they have never reached before" and save more girls from the life threatening practice. Our goal for this session is to demonstrate how mapping can help achieve SDGs in developing countries, and illustrate how easy it is to contribute by doing mapping online.
sessions.title: Towards sustainable development: crowdsourced mapping to end FGM in Tanzania

sessions.description: We’ll learn about web literacy skills in the context of library staff as we practice remixing, revising, and evaluating and composing information in an online context in a fun and interactive session.
sessions.title: Remix your own Historical Narratives-- Web Literacy Skills for Librarians

sessions.description:
Let's create a board game together that would help illustrates the challenges of being connected. Can a board game help the players develop their empathy and relate to others? Can it help them identify with other communities? Can it help build a more inclusive web? 

Think of monopoly or other plateau games, and illustrate things like:
* Visiting a certain number of web pages per day on a data-budget
* Face network connectivity difficulties
* Deal with a lack of money while participating in the mobile economy
* Browse topics written in a language you don't understand
* Stubble upon content that is not respectful and inclusive 

The goal for this session is to create the mechanisms of the games and eventually make enough progress to plan it's production.
sessions.title: Let's create a board game for empathy

sessions.description: We are building a world-class engagement platform offering tools to push forward municipal broadband in communities across Canada. We want to share this platform, and the importance of municipal broadband, with the world. Pioneering cities and towns have taken it upon themselves to close the digital divide by ensuring affordable, city-wide Internet access through municipal broadband networks. Our platform will build on the successes of these often disparate and isolated communities, and kickstart a new mass movement for municipal broadband initiatives that can be replicated anywhere. In the U.S. alone, over 100 communities have pledged to develop their own fibre, highlighting the role municipal networks can play in galvanizing the digital divide. Participants will receive a preview of our engagement platform to empower not just individuals, but entire communities, to organize in distributed, local groups, and address the digital deficits their cities and towns face.
sessions.title: Crowdsourcing the Next Gigabit Cities: An Engagement Platform for Municipal Broadband

sessions.description:
In this workshop, participants will collaborate on the design and development of a digital roadmapping tool to enhance the brokering capacities of educators and mentors including Hive members, Mozilla Clubs captains, and regional coordinators.
This tool builds off a prototype digital roadmap (DR) that was part of the inaugural CITYExpeditions, a youth pathways building program designed by members of the Mozilla Hive NYC Learning Network (The Knowledge House and CITYPathways). After each field trip to various locations in the city (e.g., science museums, technology-oriented organizations), youth documented their visit by dropping a pin on a map and reflecting on the experience via blog posts and photos. This engagement, in addition to helping young people gain familiarity with building personal pathways, represented a powerful way to begin to shape their digital world, increase digital inclusion, build web literacy, and engage with issues of online privacy and security .
sessions.title: From Broken to Brokering: Designing Digital Roadmaps to Connect Dots for Youth in Our Cities

sessions.description: One of the great detriments to the inclusion of more minorities in technology has been a lack of access. Makerspaces provide that possibility. This movement is finally being recognized as a tool for student success and a pathway to connected learning. Making provides the ability to take practical knowledge and create personally relevant projects while engaging learners, but the connection to the classroom and home life is still lacking. Maker MOB aims to reach families unfamiliar with the maker movement to create a community of makers, specifically those underrepresented in the STEM fields using students and Chicago institutions to lead STEM activities at neighborhood events. We believe that bringing these activities to families, where they are at, will create new communities of makers. Session participants will be introduced to the Maker MOB while learning how to replicate within their own communities and build the perceived value of making.

1.affiliated org: NEIU's Center for College Access and Success
1.name: C. Meghan Hausman

sessions.title: Maker MOB: Bringing STEM Making Activities to Community Events

sessions.description: My session will teach people how the basic web works through a walled community garden analogy. People will then discuss and create a web system of their own that reflects on how the web can tackle privacy, decentralization, and inclusion.
sessions.title: The Web Garden: Planting the Seeds of Knowledge About the Web

sessions.description: My session will teach people how the basic web works through a walled community garden analogy. People will then discuss and create a web system of their own that reflects on how the web can tackle privacy, decentralization, and inclusion.
sessions.title: The Web Garden: Planting the Seeds of Knowledge About the Web

sessions.description: Inspired by the Digital Skills Observatory project, a community shows us how creativity and innovation are affected by people’s stories about their relationships with technology and society, and how these stories can fuel movements. Participants get to learn empathy, to become better listeners and to engage with one another making them better story tellers as they adjust to their audience.
sessions.title: Fireplace - Gather around everyone, it's story time!

sessions.description: This workshop will focus on identifying tools, developing frameworks, and creating learning activities for teens to read, write, and participate in teen-led, open-source inquiry projects. Mozilla’s Web Literacy Framework, Science Lab’s Working in the Open Workshop and Open Research Accelerator, “Open Leadership Training Series” (in development), and other resources provide tools that can be forked and remixed to create resources for teens and adult allies to launch their own open projects. The focus will be on participatory projects that do *not* involve a lot of code (if any), encompassing a range of fields from science to social justice to art. Session participants will ground their work using select Mozilla Web Literacy “Write” and “Participate” competencies including “Compose”, “Revise”, “Share”,  “Contribute”, “Open Practice”, and “Connect”. The goal is to lay the foundation for the further development of accessible resources for any teen to create, discover, and contribute to open-source inquiry projects.

1.affiliated org: Chicago Academy of Sciences / Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum
1.name: David Bild

sessions.title: Teen Leadership, Open-Source Inquiry, and Working in the Open

sessions.description:
Content on the internet has become freer, cheaper, and faster, with a seemingly endless amount of content clogging our brains and inboxes. This content is passed around on a variety of platforms, but what does it mean for open licensing, transparency, and the commons when most things feel free to users even if they aren't open? What does it mean to share the latest viral photo, video, or GIF when you want to work in the open? Why does the distinction between free and open matter?
This interactive session will help participants question how and what they share on the Web and why content that's free is not necessarily open. After exploring these issues, participants will dream up a new technology or platform they would utilize or create to make creativity thrive in the open on the Web we want.
sessions.title: Why choose open when you can choose free?: A discussion of some of the issues surrounding free content on the Web

sessions.description: We’ll be hacking on our new “What is the good of a gig?” curriculum on Sunday morning October 30th in the “Open Circle” section of the Demystify the Web Space, and we welcome you to drop in and give us feedback about this new workshop while it is in its early stages of development.
sessions.title: What Good Can Gigabit Networks Do? Curriculum Hack

sessions.description:
Zeynep Tufekci, a professor at the University of North Carolina and contributor to the New York Times, will speak about digital inclusion and decentralization.

Brian Behlendorf, the Executive Director of the Hyperledger Project will give a talk titled “Bringing Back the Decentralized Web, with Blockchains and Other New Tools.”

And Maggie Vail, the Executive Director of CASH Music, will speak about web literacy.

Each talk will be followed by a brief, moderated Q&A and will be streamed live on https://facebook.com/mozilla
sessions.title: Dialogues & Debates: Zeynep Tufekci, Brian Behlendorf & Maggie Vail

sessions.description:
Mark Surman, Executive Director of the Mozilla Foundation, will speak about Mozilla's five key issues.

And Sahar Aziz, Professor of Law at Texas A&M University, will speak about privacy, security, and digital inclusion.

Each talk will be followed by a brief, moderated Q&A and will be streamed live on https://facebook.com/mozilla
sessions.title: Dialogues & Debates: Mark Surman & Sahar Aziz

sessions.description:
Katherine Maher, Executive Director of the Wikimedia Foundation, will speak about the open internet movement.

Chris Soghoian, Principal Technologist & Senior Policy Analyst at the ACLU, will speak about privacy and security.

And Ashe Dryden, White House Fellow, will give a talk titled "The Ethics of Unpaid Labor and Open Source Software."

Each talk will be followed by a brief, moderated Q&A and will be streamed live on https://facebook.com/mozilla
sessions.title: Dialogues & Debates: Katherine Maher, Chris Soghoian & Ashe Dryden

sessions.description:
Volker Birk, CTO of pretty Easy privacy and President of the p≡p Foundation Council, will speak about privacy and security.

And Katharina Borchert, Chief Innovation Officer at Mozilla, will speak about equal rating.

Each talk will be followed by a brief, moderated Q&A and will be streamed live on https://facebook.com/mozilla
sessions.title: Dialogues & Debates: Volker Birk & Katharina Borchert

sessions.description:
Simone Browne, Professorat University of Texas at Austin, will speak about privacy, security, and digital inclusion.

And Eliot Higgins, Founder of Bellingcat and Brown Moses blog, will give a talk titled "The End of Secrets: Conflict in the Engagement Age."

Each talk will be followed by a brief, moderated Q&A and will be streamed live on https://facebook.com/mozilla
sessions.title: Dialogues & Debates: Simone Browne & Eliot Higgins

sessions.description: The new Web Animations API standards offer powerful tools for developers to use code to add animation to their web apps. But there's a lot more to this API than tools for programmers. There's new opportunities for artists and others to learn and use these digital tools for creative expression and fun.
sessions.title: Web Animation for Artists & Others

sessions.description: The new Web Animations API standards offer powerful tools for developers to use code to add animation to their web apps. But there's a lot more to this API than tools for programmers. There's new opportunities for artists and others to learn and use these digital tools for creative expression and fun.
sessions.title: Web Animation for Artists & Others

sessions.description:
EK Theater will present a workshop of “Niobe,” a piece from the company’s repertoire, based on a story from Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this video game puppetry piece, Apollo is re-imagined as a sniper in Halo: Reach, and the performance uses two system-linked Xbox 360 consoles. The workshop will be led by director Eddie Kim and several volunteers from the Mozilla community.

After demonstrations of scenes from “Niobe,” workshop participants will be introduced to the company’s video game puppetry techniques and be given opportunities to perform in scenes.

In addition to demonstrating the relevance of classics in this digital age, EK Theater hopes to inspire others to tell their own stories using video games with this workshop.
Note: the workshop will use the video game Halo: Reach, a first-person shooter game
sessions.title: Video Game Puppetry Workshop with EK Theater

sessions.description:
EK Theater will present a workshop of “Niobe,” a piece from the company’s repertoire, based on a story from Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this video game puppetry piece, Apollo is re-imagined as a sniper in Halo: Reach, and the performance uses two system-linked Xbox 360 consoles. The workshop will be led by director Eddie Kim and several volunteers from the Mozilla community.

After demonstrations of scenes from “Niobe,” workshop participants will be introduced to the company’s video game puppetry techniques and be given opportunities to perform in scenes.

In addition to demonstrating the relevance of classics in this digital age, EK Theater hopes to inspire others to tell their own stories using video games with this workshop.
Note: the workshop will use the video game Halo: Reach, a first-person shooter game
sessions.title: Video Game Puppetry Workshop with EK Theater

sessions.description:
The Art of Vlogging (15 mins) suitable for everyone
Agi K, an award winning young filmmaker and vlogger www.agik.co.uk will host a talk with demo and Q & A about Art’s role in vlogging futures.
Participants will have a Demo on how to use digital media inventively in vlogging. Learning a range of creative techniques. This will be followed by a discussion about:
-How artists can use art to evolve vlogging genres?
-How artists can use vlogging as a tool for sharing their work and reaching mass audiences?

1,2,3, Vlog, Edit, Upload, suitable for ages 12 plus (90 mins) (30 participants)
Agi K, young vlogger and filmmaker and Anita Kolaczynska, Arts Award Adviser, will facilitate a practical workshop on vlogging at live events.

Participants will learn how to use reportage and art techniques creatively to make an exciting, compelling vlog. They will watch a ‘how to’ example vlog, discuss and brainstorm in groups (with paper and sharpies) how to shoot engaging footage discussing elements like camera angles, speech, pace, visuals, humour. They will then have a vlogging race to go capture the essence of Mozfest shooting as much relevant footage as they can in 15 minutes. In pairs they will be shooting this footage in the style of 'dialogue vlog’ each pair commenting on different areas/aspects of Mozfest. Return to base to listen to a lightening talk about adding artistry through their editing of their footage. Then prepare to edit by making art to enhance their vlog with paper and sharpies), shoot this and any extra sound effects, titles, stills needed. Then use their editing phone apps to creatively edit their footage to create buzzing 50 second vlogs.
Upload to Arts Award Voice. They will then be projected onto a screen to be watched by all. Everyone will be encouraged to tweet, comment and share, whilst watching.
sessions.title: The Art of Vlogging and 1,2,3 Vlog Edit Upload

sessions.description: The Moz-Stand: get the buzz, is a one stop shop for all your MozFest updates. Keep on top of Festival highlights and news with this retro-newsstand inspired interactive booth. Stock up on MozFest souvenirs, with physical Snapchat filters, customised postcards and printed Festival newspaper, and don't miss a minute of social content with our live ticker tape updates! Also, make sure you're following ‘mfestival’ over the weekend to keep up to date with all the action.
sessions.title: The Moz-Stand: Get the Buzz

sessions.description:
Using our new OHG Gaming Hub visitors (young people, adults, and families) will be able to design an avatar or gaming element using a range of hands on drawing/crafting techniques, taking inspiration from the people, collection and architecture of Orleans House Gallery. The artwork will then be scanned and uploaded to our platform and visitors can then drop it into their own game, either on a laptop or computer or on their own device during the workshop or at home.
Please check out our gaming hub http://ohggaminghub.co.uk to see and play on some of the existing games- please note the hub is still under construction but will be finished in time for Mozfest. Visitors will be able to play, build upon and share their game and others games after the workshop.
sessions.title: Orleans House Gallery Gaming Hub: GAME ON!

sessions.description: The Mercury Theatre, Colchester, run a summer school for young people called hACkT, fusing theatre making with video game design and accessible technologies. This fireside chat will focus on the cross over between traditional art forms and emergent technologies and how a theatre can take an innovative approach to learning and participation for young people. We will share examples of activity and talk through our new methodologies such as using choreography to teach coding. Our drive is to demonstrate that STEM subjects need to be seen as creative and that the agenda should embrace the arts and move to STEAM. Additionally we’ll share how we embedded Arts Award into a week of activity.
sessions.title: hACkT: Drama and Technology for Creative Learning

sessions.description: During the session a group of young volunteers aged 15-18 will talk about their film-making project and will present a trailer of their film which showcases creativity in the Royal Borough of Greenwich. This will be part of a week-long film-making project taking place during the October holidays, in which the young volunteers will work towards achieving their Bronze Arts Award. This presentation will contribute towards an element of their Arts Award, sharing their film-making process and the skills they have learnt along the way.
sessions.title: Creative Greenwich – a film project by and for young people

sessions.description:
A dedicated space to join an ongoing conversation about how we as educators, artists, and technologists can better understand the intersection of art, advocacy, and digital literacy. This could include unique tools, conversations, or learning resources.  This conversation is ideal for all those representating education, digital literacy, youth work and the arts who want to gain a stronger understanding of these topics.

The aim of the session and it's fringe event taking place at Tate Modern is to build  a set of resources and individuals interested in advocating for a free and open internet, teaching youth, empowering citizens, and able to use art as a vehicle for all those things.
sessions.title: Digital Literacy & Culture: On the Intersection of Art, Education, & Advocacy

sessions.description:
Can a computer make art? Sure. Can you make art with a computer? Absolutely! Even if you (think you) have never written code before.
In this practical workshop you will learn how to make a bot that tweets your generative art.
We will use [CheapBotsDoneQuick](http://cheapbotsdonequick.com), a tool that does the heavy lifting (Twitter API and such) so that we can focus on being creative with language and graphics.
sessions.title: Making bots that make art

sessions.description:
Imagine a performance stage that uses ethernetted cameras, Raspberry Pi computers, and computer vision software to respond to dancer and performer movement programmatically with music.

Workshop participants will use the Stage Genie response composition app to collaboratively soundscape the 'stage' (can be anywhere). Stage Genie will visually track an on-stage object (simplified for the workshop) and play music, tones, samples etc. for each position in the 3D space above the stage.

Once workshop participants complete their soundscapes, we'll invite all MozFest attendees to improvise dance or musical performances on the stage to experience first-hand the possibilities of response composition as an art form.
sessions.title: Stage Genie Response Composition Workshop

sessions.description:
Join Arts Award Voice for an interactive session where we give you the basic skills required to start your own blogging adventure. 

Arts Award Voice is an online magazine which writes about art and culture. The target audience is 16-25, although our content is universally accessible, and an interesting read regardless of age or interest - if we do say so ourselves!

Working with trained journalists, we will look at the basics of writing an article, how to conduct an interview, and how to upload to Arts Award Voice. You will then be given a writing brief, and invited to report on the festival for us, uploading to the website at your leisure. Your blogs could be seen by our thousands of readers, and you get to say your blog is posted on Voice! 

So if you want to attend a session that will help you express your opinions, help you review the festival, or if you just want to ask an expert editor and trained journalist some industry tips, this is the session for you!
sessions.title: Digital Arts Journalism with Arts Award Voice

sessions.description:
An interactive online graphic novel challenging you to move through a ‘perfect’ world, create the ‘perfect’ person and interact with what you find. Come and explore: www.curingperfect.com #CuringPerfect
See the process behind the making of Curing Perfect, an interactive online graphic novel, created by a team of learning disabled artists supported by Carousel, an arts organisation helping learning disabled artists to achieve their ambitions.
See original drawings, storyboards and meet the artists.

Experience Curing Perfect, the online graphic novel, on five laptops. You make your way as a reject in perfect world, solving puzzles, reflecting on questions and making choices.
Participants will learn about the underlying ethical issues that gene therapy and stem cell research poses. What is ‘perfect’ and who decides? Participants will be challenged to consider these big questions as presented by the team of learning disabled artists.
sessions.title: Curing Perfect Interactive Online Graphic Novel

sessions.description:
In a piece of music, musical fragments must come in a coherent series if the music is to make sense. Mozart (260th year this year) devised a clever game in the 18th century by throwing dice to make apparently “random” choices from a grid of musical examples. Thus an appropriate example is always selected. Whether or not the dice player understands to the process, s/he will always produce a coherent piece. Using a coded process the “player” can create a piece with even less prior musical knowledge.

The digital form of the game allows the participant much more flexibility to examine patterns as between music and coding. With a minimum of formal musical knowledge, the participant can gain insights into patterns and how they work.

Be prepared!
Please down load the link https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0Bz__LQ1ATjtWZjdrbjlRYlRxVEU?usp=sharing
You’ll need this for maximum participation to compose your own unique piece of music!

1.affiliated org: West London Arts Scene (Ealing Autumn Festival) and  Libraries and CCS (Cultural Community Solutions) partnering in the Truth and Reconciliation project
1.name: Gillian Spragg

sessions.title: The Digital MozArt

sessions.description:
Come along and meet with the Digital Maker Collective, an interdisciplinary interest led gathering of arts staff, students and alumni from the University of the Arts London. The Collective explore and critique digital making, emergent
digital practice, collaboration and the sharing economy.  At MozFest members of the Collective will share art school perspectives of digital practice as well as exploring related connections across digital projects, concepts & technologies. Expect environment-mapping, interactive virtual worlds, creative uses of glitches, utopian art schools, photogrammetry, bio feedback devices, web & artistic agency and art school play with virtual reality HTC vive/Tiltbrush.

1.affiliated org: Digital Maker Collective, University of the Arts London
1.name: Chris Follows

sessions.title: Digital Maker Collective: Exploring emergent digital practice in the arts

sessions.description:
Behind every beautiful blog, site and app there are countless lines of code. In June, we activated our Mozilla Open Mic program to launch #TheArtofCoding, an Instagram-based campaign leveraging our community, as well as bloggers in creative industries like fashion, art, food, and DIY, to illustrate that learning to code can be a way to open up a new world of self expression online.
We’ll share a short case study of the work so far and then get session-goers engaged in creating their own visual representations of code to inspire others to see the hidden connection between art & code through making.
sessions.title: The Art of Coding

sessions.description: This session will encourage people to awaken their inner creator by teaching them creative product management through hands-on design. From a complex idea, participants will work as a team to turn that idea into a product while being walked through some of the most important product design/management principles. This promises to be a fun session mixing up technology, problem solving, creativity, arts and the web.
sessions.title: Unleash the Creator in You!

sessions.description: In the last few months I have attended several conferences and realised I really like to sktech my notes. I'll use this new art form to help Mozfest participants to share their experiences of the festival in our dedicated sharing zone in the Digital Arts and Culture space - come take a look and join in!  This is a drop in session throughout the day.
sessions.title: Having fun sketching notes

sessions.description: In the last few months I have attended several conferences and realised I really like to sktech my notes. I'll use this new art form to help Mozfest participants to share their experiences of the festival in our dedicated sharing zone in the Digital Arts and Culture space - come take a look and join in!  This is a drop in session throughout the day.
sessions.title: Having fun sketching notes

sessions.title: Having fun sketching notes

sessions.description:
Take part in a digital orchestra using iPads as sound makers. Shape the composition process, rehearse and perform a piece of music in one hour.
Regardless of age or ability participants will get a high quality musical experience and will develop their ensemble playing skills using the iPad as an instrument. They will learn the basics of musical arrangement, musical elements e.g. tempo, pitch etc. following a conductor as well as the basic knowledge in the use of a range of iPad apps for music.

1.affiliated org: A Little Learning with Transformance Music
1.name: Dave Darch

sessions.title: iPad Orchestra

sessions.description: The session will explore creating visual art via coding and robotics. Participants will learn and use creative code to create pieces of art. The seesion will cater for a range of abilities as there will be a combination of  default programmed algorithms, load sample scripts and tweak parameters  and write completely new code. The participants will collaborative create artwork. The session will be co-led/supported by young coder-artists from East London.
sessions.title: Ro-Botticelli, Creating Art with Robots

sessions.description:
We'll unpack what 'storytelling' means, via a structured model, discussed here: 
https://medium.com/@r4isstatic/the-s-word-fe02b09541f#.h1kzc7wj1 
and https://medium.com/@r4isstatic/a-three-part-model-for-understanding-stories-d0933f4d7460#.6vztqzkwx.

By looking at the techniques and craft of storytelling from TV, film and online media, we'll discuss what each technique helps achieve, why, and what equivalents might be found in online and digital spaces. We'll also consider the idea of 'structured journalism' and the Web as a medium for exploring hyperlinked narratives.
sessions.title: Beyond the Hero's Journey - What do we mean when we talk about 'storytelling'?

sessions.description: Participants will be able to create music using physical objects connected to sensors, so they will be able to express their creativity and produce fantastic songs that could be recorded and share after they finish.
sessions.title: Music From Things

sessions.description:
The session will support young people in developing projects using the BBC micro:bit relevant to the Bronze Arts Award. Based on worksheets already prepared and trialled by Arts Award and tutorial material from the microbit.co.uk website.  

For those working towards Arts Award, this session will cover Bronze Part A (explore the arts as a participant), we will then send participants to other zones and to explore MozEx so that they can gather evidence towards towards Part B (explore the arts as an audience member).

This session will be co-delivered with young people.
sessions.title: Bronze Arts Award with BBC micro:bit

sessions.description:
A Fireside Chat all about using digital technology to break the barriers to the arts for young disabled people.

With a focus on diversity, access and creativity, Shape’s Young Leaders Forum will join forces with Wac Arts to instigate ideas for using digital technology to make the arts more accessible to young disabled people. 

All of our work at Shape is informed by the Social Model of Disability which, by focusing on the disabling barriers imposed by society, embraces all physical, sensory and invisible impairments, learning disability, mental health, neurodiverse and fatigue conditions. The role of organisational systems and cultures in all sectors of society is vital in implementing lasting changes and remove barriers for any disabled person to access and experience the arts. 

We will adopt an open space technology approach to engage disabled and non-disabled people in constructive dialogue and knowledge exchange about the use of technology and the web to enhance cultural learning and arts
progression for young disabled people.
sessions.title: Open about disability online

sessions.description:
An interactive workshop acorss the miles focussing on digital music collaboration!

There are current frustrations and areas for experimentation around making and sharing music to further collaborate and create final pieces. This can impact on the quality of the experience for participants and audiences.

We will create a remote/online experiment to explore the effectiveness of music making and digital sharing for a global audience in the following areas:
1)        Exploring ‘latency’ in ‘real-time’ music collaborations online
2)        Understanding the challenges of live streaming for jamming between remote locales (tutorial to performance)
3)        Experimenting with musical segments//rifs to compose mixes using current technology/platforms, e.g.  recent applications like Whole World Band

The workshop will be co-facilitated live by a group for young people in Northumberland.

A final Q & A will be central to the experiment, giving us time to progress ideas, experiments continue conversations after MozFest.
sessions.title: Off the Beat - Digital Collaboration

sessions.description:
Drake Music (DM) are specialist in using Assistive Music Technology (AMT) to overcome disabling barriers to making music.

A variety of of-the-shelf  AMT, such as iPads, beams, switches and microphones, and will be set up so that participants can drop in and have a go during the first hour.

We will  have bespoke AMT on show such as the Mui Mui Gloves http://bit.ly/MiMKH and the Kellycaster http://bit.ly/kellycast, as well low tech ideas developed in our R&D programme in the classroom, http://bit.ly/DMLRnD with young people.

Participants will be able to see it in action as well as  jump in and have a go, have a play, jam and make music.

During the second half of the session there will also be an opportunity for groups to  work together to create a piece of music, facilitated by our expert DM Associate Musicians (AMs) .
sessions.title: DMLab Live

sessions.description: This session introduces WebVR and how to start developing virtual reality applications using the web browser. We’ll share some of the possibilities and develop a rapid prototype through simple markup, using A-Frame.
sessions.title: Getting Started with Virtual Reality for the Web

sessions.description:
A lab to highlight the work that the BBC and partners are doing in the space of 360 and VR, including a presenation and time for questions.

What we are excited about and what direction we see things heading in in the short to mid term. We'll also cover how the BBC is looking to take advantage of these technologies, the challenges we are facing and the lessons we have learnt so far.
sessions.title: VR and 360 video at BBC

sessions.description: Bots are popping up all over the place: making art, fighting parking tickets or helping us learn a foreign language. In this session we'll look at some innovative bots and then make our own using GitHub, PythonAnywhere and the Twitter API (no coding experience necessary). To celebrate the bicentenary of the Brontë sisters these simple bots will tweet in the words of Charlotte, Emily or Anne. We will also imagine the perfect culture bot, brainstorming ideas for more sophisticated creations. Please set up a Twitter account before attending.

1.affiliated org: University of York / The National Archives
1.name: Jo Pugh

sessions.title: Culturebots and AnneDroid Brontës

sessions.description:
The large number of initiatives to digitise medieval manuscripts, and the unprecedented access this has allowed, could be compared to the early years of the printing press. But what can we do with this treasure trove of online material beyond the "turning the pages" model? 

In this session, we will explore a range of different technologies for studying medieval texts, handwriting and manuscript illuminations. In particular, we will look at computer-assisted tools for annotating medieval manuscripts and summarise the thinking behind our own work on the open source DigiPal framework (digipal.eu). 

Participants will learn about technologies for marking-up manuscripts and how visualisation techniques allow us to further nuance our understanding of the medieval cultures that produced these artefacts.
sessions.title: Getting Medieval, Getting Manuscripts

sessions.description:
The Learning Portfolio Builder is an online/hybrid platform that provides access to digital literacy and design skills for  students.

I have been working with US highschool students who are passionate about art and design but struggle balancing their passion with their daily life; they have school, jobs, and sometimes kids of their own.

Current traditional educational models don't support under served highschool students in terms of accessibility, cost of education, and schedule of programmes in relation to their personal lives and economic struggles.

In 2012, the National Endowment for the Arts study addressed the importance of Intensive Arts Education in relation to college access, persistance, and completion. We need a paradigm shift that transforms institutions' mindsets, and that allows students to adapt to new learning environments that prepare them for future job.

This session will allow participants to get a taste of a hybrid course, and produce a design piece, with a face-to-face component.

1.affiliated org: Parsons, The New School for Design
1.name: Niberca Polo

sessions.title: Learning Portfolio Builder

sessions.description:
The Research & Education Space (RES) programme is an initiative to bring the nation’s public archives to education across the UK, from primary to University level using Linked Open Data.

Sounds easy, right? Especially when you’re the BBC, Jisc and Learning on Screen.
Come and find out why we’ve been building the Research & Education Space, why it’s not that easy after all, where our three years of work has got us to, and how you can get involved.
The session will provide an opportunity for developers, collection-holders, teachers, academics and students to see what we’ve done—including how to use our API, ask us questions and give us their suggestions on how to improve it.
sessions.title:
How hard could it be? — Building the Research &
Education Space

sessions.description:
We'll create an interactive AR trail of the festival and its spaces for participants to explore MozEx exhibits in each space.  

Participants can download the Gamar app before the day or on the day for their device.  They can use the AR trail to discover the festival and its activities.  

Those interested in how the trail is created and in scanning some of their own  AR stops at the festival can join us in the Arts and Culture space to demo our CMS and help us to develop the trail over the weekend.

With Gamar's new online platform now launched for museums and cultural settings to create their own trail, we are
sure to see lots more organisations joining Gamar! 

This experience will run all weekend.  Come find us to get started!
sessions.title: Exploring MozFest with Gamar

sessions.description:
Engaging festival goers around their ideas of creative code, by making flags/banners. Participants will use a set of precut icons and letters to create messages, combining them with a special set of shapes that act as a code-like vocabulary. As these are produced over Saturday, they will get inched out across the atrium, italian clothes-line style. Participants can collect them on Sunday in the last hours of the festival.

This activity will take place throughout the festival
sessions.title: Flags: When is code at its most creative?

sessions.description:
People will learn basic skills to form a concept for a website/webapp by using InDesign.

I will show how to use InDesign in the designing process considering responsiveness and creating a nice and appealing interface.

Please donwload a trial version of InDesign (if not installed yet):

https://creative.adobe.com/products/download/indesign
sessions.title: Is InDesign a legitimate tool to form a design concept for website/webapp with an appealing user interface?

sessions.description: this short talk is a call to arms, or hands rather, a call to action, a proposal of how to see through the corporate web to the web as it once was, a web in the making.
sessions.title: A Handmade Web

sessions.description: This session will share the story, and exhibit the output, of a collaboration between the Ravensbourne Graphic Design BA course and the Met Office. Students will discuss the different methods of weather data visualisation, particularly with regards to catering to specific-interest groups. They will draw on their own experiences of a collaborative project run with the Met Office, showcase their own visualisations (both online and offline) and talk about their development. It is hoped that this will provide a framework for discussion about data visualisation in a broader sense, drawing on the perspectives of both scientists and designers. Session participants will hopefully also be inspired by the collaboration between students and industry, potentially leading to further partnership opportunities within the design and scientific communities. Finally the students who won the weather data project will also exhibit a special Moz Fest edition of 'Hack Circus' they co-created with the Met Office.
sessions.title: Ravensbourne Graphic Design x Met Office Collaboration

sessions.description: Artificial intelligence offers new efficiencies & opportunities for local services; as banal as routes for collecting bins, as critical as where to build fire stations, as fraught as predicting crime and child abuse. These debates involve deep ethical quandaries and entrenched discrimination, squeamishness about robot overlords, and problems in our population's data literacy, with lives, families and the safety and basic functions of our homes at stake. People are already deciding whether to allow these AI services into their communities in real-life debates in the US and New Zealand and they're on their way to the UK. Join us and a panel of experts to debate real and near-future AI services coming to a town near you.
sessions.title: Town Hall 2020: Should an AI run your council services?

sessions.description: The Museum of Technorealism seeks to both reenact and rearticulate the original principles of the 1998 Technorealism movement through specific artefacts drawn from the tides of technological transformation. Technorealism asks that we think more critically about the role that technology plays in human evolution and everyday life. Integral to this perspective is an understanding that the current waves of technological transformation are actually a continuation of tides of change that have taken place throughout history.
sessions.title: The Museum of Technorealism

sessions.description: In this hour people will learn what Dowse is and why we are building it, how they can get aboard with developing, marketing, and creating an IoT awareness around it , all in the context of creating Internet of Neighborhoods instead of 'smart cities'.
sessions.title: Dowse.eu  The Privacy Hub for the Internet of Things

sessions.description:
In collaboration with BBC R&D, Nottingham, Cambridge and Queen Mary universities present the Databox - www.databoxproject.uk - to drive community engagement with and discussion of the dilemmas of connected spaces. The Databox allows people to control access to personal data generated by Internet-enabled things, and allows them to exploit that data for their own benefit.
Lucky participations will take part in making a cold chocolate dessert in front of a live audience, following a novel ‘object-based media’ recipe that exploits data from their interactions with Internet-enabled appliances, utensils and food packaging to deliver timely and appropriate video instructions.
Getting your hands on our connected future will drive discussion of the positives and negatives of using the personal data produced in our mundane interactions with everyday things to drive new media experiences.
Of course participants will also be able to eat and enjoy the fruits of their labour.
Bon appétit!
sessions.title: The Kitchen Databox Demo

sessions.description: The Databox - www.databoxproject.uk - provides a radical alternative to widespread data harvesting and data processing ‘in the cloud’. Instead data processing takes place ‘on the box’ and is limited to what is needed to deliver specific services. We introduce the Databox platform to the Mozilla community and provide participants with the opportunity to get their hands on this novel privacy-preserving platform. This hands on session will exploit data provided by Internet of Things devices deployed around the Mozilla Festival. Participants will be provided with a brief overview of the Databox platform before being invited to build ‘apps’ that sit on the Databox. Exploiting a modified Node Red app-building environment, participants will discover how to make apps that respect the requirement of informed consent and allow individuals to exercise granular choice over data processing; choices which are translated into enforceable policies on the Databox and govern data access and use.
sessions.title: Databox: Hack an App

sessions.description: The complexity of the Internet of Things means that a growing number of tasks in the future smart home will have to be handed over to computational agents and autonomous systems. Automation is problematic however, creating risks to privacy and impacting trust. This proposal seeks to engage the Mozilla community in understanding the dilemmas that emerge when connected spaces become autonomous. Workshop participants will be introduced to a range of storyboards illustrating utopian and dystopian visions of a future autonomous home. By encouraging participants to reflect on these envisioned futures, our aim is to spark a discussion that will help uncover some of the critical challenges confronting autonomous systems and the kinds of interfaces that are needed by human beings to control these systems. In addition to making an engaging contribution to the Mozilla Festival, the results of the workshop will inform development of the Autonomous Internet of Things http://a-iot.org
sessions.title: Critical Challenges and Interfaces to Autonomous Systems

sessions.description: The time is right to not only ask what is possible for IoT, but what is responsible. We're learning how to embed internet health in the making of meaningful connected things. We're looking at issues like privacy & security, decentralization and open innovation in IoT. Join IoT professionals working in the field alongside local communities to produce research, prototypes and best practices that demonstrate how Mozilla's principles can be implemented in connected products.
sessions.title: Welcome to the Open IoT Studio!

sessions.description: Learn about low power wide area networks like The Things Network and how we build the network together with more than 200 communities world wide. They will make a thing, connected to the network
sessions.title: Building a connected thing

sessions.description:
Imagine only needing to hover under a street lamp to get public internet access, or downloading a movie from the lamp on your desk. There's a new technology on the block which could, quite literally as well as metaphorically, 'throw light on' how to meet the ever-increasing demand for high-speed wireless connectivity. Radio waves are replaced by light waves in a new method of data transmission which is being called Li-Fi. Light-emitting diodes can be switched on and off faster than the human eye can detect, causing the light source to appear to be on continuously.
The session will mainly consist of the demo of the Light Bulb
Prototype that We have designed that can be used to transfer data at a speed of 2Mbps.
sessions.title: Light Fidelity- Data transfer using Light Bulbs

sessions.description: The University of Nottingham and BBC R&D are working together on user interaction methods to support trustworthy data transactions between users and service providers. This workshop looks at this in the context of the connected home. Using scenarios, prompts and materials you will work together to build your own connected home and design your own control hub to interact with this connected ecosystem. The workshop focuses on negotiating challenges and coming up with practical solutions for interacting with these connected systems, helping to identify design principles that can help support trustworthy data interactions in connected homes of the future.

1.affiliated org: University of Nottingham and BBC R&D
1.name: Neelima Sailaja

sessions.title: IoT: Usable privacy in the connected home

sessions.description:
Activity - engaging citizen scientists and analytics experts:
Attendees will be taught the basic principles of Human Centric Lighting and how the body’s organ functions are directly linked to the rise and fall of the sun. From NASA to horticulturists, light is increasingly recognised as a drug for living organisms. If used correctly, light can improve sleep as well as focus.
Experiment with Smart Diffuser and experience the effects of the light:
Based on research carried out in classrooms, offices and even on the International Space Station, attendees will be able to program a set of Quantum Dot enhanced lights (the Smart Diffuser TM) to shift colour temperature over a 10 minute period and find out the effect on their body. Nano-Lit will stream the data collected in real time to an online server to see if results are valuable and what they tell us about Human Centric Lighting.
sessions.title: Is Light a Supplement?

sessions.description: APC and its partners have re-released its popular resource, a simple first-aid for human rights defenders who have found themselves on the receiving end of a hack, DDoS, or severe trolling. The latest edition is even more usable: mobile responsive and on a standalone platform. It's also now in Urdu, Hindi, French and Spanish, in addition to the original English. Participants will be coerced into a gameshow format as a way to share expertise and cluelessness alike in figuring out exactly what to do once you've been pwned.
sessions.title: An exceedingly practical digital security first-aid kit for after you've been pwned

sessions.description: James Watt, the pioneer of steam power, had a workshop at the University of Glasgow where all his friends discussed how different tools and machines could be redesigned and improved. We will talk about Watt’s legacy and show some of the things that came out of his discussions: the first machine for duplicating writing; a new type of organ; a sculpture copying machine. Inspired by Watt’s workshop and inventions, we will take some everyday objects (kettles, vases, scissors, plates, screwdriver, pliers, pen, book, etc.) and thinking about how they could be rethought. We will have a selection of these objects available and will take them apart, look at how they work and discuss how they can be rethought. We will produce some short video presentations on our new inventions.
sessions.title: Steampunk with James Watt

sessions.description: The reality of innovation in 2016 is that the best ideas can come from anywhere.  This session will show that with encouragement , reassurance and a safe environment anyone can contribute to generating, selecting and refining great innovations.
sessions.title: Open Innovators

sessions.description: The session builds on the conception of the ‘Code of the Dark Temple’ <darktemple.net> at the UnBox Caravan in Feb, 2016 in India. In a nutshell, the ‘code’ is a manifesto that encodes certain principles for the ‘right to disconnect’ in an evermore connected world. One of the lines of inquiry taken forward from that manifesto was to write a set of stories that envisioned the embracing of these principles in a near future. The session at MozFest would present some of this initial work, and guide the participants in the workshop to contribute more stories and creative methods of representation.

1.affiliated org: The Monks of The Dark Temple
1.name: Vladan Joler, Monk of The Dark Temple.

facilitators_names: Vladan Joler, Monk of The Dark Temple.
sessions.title: Writing a future history for the Code of the Dark Temple

sessions.description:
This session in short will build on a talk by Dietrich and me
Sensors to Signals: Using old phones for IoT. In the session I will very briefly talk about the previous work on how we could use our old phones as a sensor device to collect data and convert them to signals. Then I will go on showing what we can build on top of that and how to actually use methods to infer about well being of a person form those data.
I will be showing them demo based on data collected from my phone and fitness band throughout my last 6 months and what could be inferred from it and how accurate or wrong they are!
sessions.title: Are you well? When connected devices know more about you

sessions.description: Toys began as homemade things, often made by children themselves to designs passed down through generations.  The growth of the maker community, the capacity of the Internet to share ideas and the delight of a successful make, 3D printing, and more, should enable a resurgence of delightful, quirky, cheap, amazing, personal, empowering, life changing TOYS!  Let's make some!
sessions.title: Future toys

sessions.description:
Casa Jasmina is an experimental project started with the goal of developing an open source connected home.
Making the home accessible and liveable to people ( and not just to geeks) has been one of the most interesting challenges.
What kind of interfaces are really usable? How can you explain visitor what the devices in the apartment do? how to protect privacy of a smart home guest?
sessions.title: Chatting with the smart home

sessions.description:
Have you ever chatted with a device?
Conversational User interfaces are becoming incredibly popular. without the need of installing new custom apps are letting user access all sort of services.
Telegram has released a powerful set of API to develop bot. And we have been experimenting with it since the very beginning.
At some point we develop an Arduino Library to host telegram bot on tiny Arduino devices. Allowing users to chat with their weather Arduino projects to get sensor data and or remotely control devices.
Join the workshop to develop your first chat bot that interact with the physical world.
sessions.title: Telegram bot meets Arduino

sessions.description:
Imagine decorating your world with beautiful interactive patterns. Artcodes makes this possible!

Artcodes is a new technology that allows users to interact with all manner of decorative imagery and patterns. As part of collaborative research between both designers and computer scientists at the University of Nottingham, funded by Horizon Digital Economy Research and the RCUK, we have developed a new interaction technology that relies upon drawing and creativity to drive it.

With artcodes you can: scan decorative patterns to trigger digital content, make existing patterns point at your content and learn how to draw your own interactive patterns.
sessions.title: Interactive Wallpaper

sessions.description:
Artcodes presents storicodes. Our new narrative app.

Our team have created a stunning interactive wall illustration called Stalker where we ask you to join the Stalker rebellion……

We are Stalkers, the resistance…….
We desperately need your help to defeat our enemy.
We are searching for the brave, the adventurous, the exceptional, the curious, the risk taker, for those of you who are strong enough to stand up for the truth and justice.

We are Stalkers, and we are all that stands between the Thakens and the complete destruction of our planet, the destruction of everything and everyone we love……. And when they have finished with our planet, they will come for yours.
Do you have what it takes to join us in our fight against the Thakens?
Do you have teh courage to step into our world of mystery, intrigue and surprise?
Do you dare to take part, solve the clues and complete your mission?
If you are the person we are looking for please help us, a message is waiting for you.

Download the storicodes app. To activate our inter-dimensional communication device. Scan the image of the journal in the large picture and begin your journey.

Good Luck
Thanks you for your help
Preserve and Protect.
