sessions.description:
A fun customisable, interactive advent calendar to use with the Christmas with Artcodes app. We would like to invite you to be the first in creating your very own interactive calendar in our one hour workshop session, where we will help you adapt and personalise your calendar to take home with you. 

The calendar comes with 24 Artcode stickers you can put under any doors. When these stickers are scanned by the Christmas with Artcodes app on a smart phone or tablet they open a digital surprise. 

Learn how to draw your own Artcodes and how to connect your Artcodes to your own pictures, videos or music. A fun way of creating your own interactive art!
sessions.title: Future Present

sessions.description:
This hands-on workshop will use the ConnectUs toolkit (see codeme.io) , consisting of interactive cubes developed to get people of all ages engaged with critically thinking about and designing for the Internet of Things (IoT). The main aims of this workshop will be to present a few of the potential problems of the IoT (e.g., sensor reliability and privacy) in a personal, hands-on and engaging way.
In the first part of the workshop, participants will explore the SenseMe toolkit through a series of mysterious, interactive activities involving sensors, LED lights and Bluetooth. These activities will be coupled with discussion about sensor reliability and data privacy in the context of the IoT.
In the second half of the workshops, using the Arduino IDE, participants will re-program the toolkit in small groups, creating IoT-inspired applications that take into account the potential IoT problems explored in the first part of the workshop.
sessions.title: SenseMe, ConnectUs: a hands-on exploration of issues with the IoT

sessions.description:
Imagine a city full of rental bikes. These retrofit rentals are super cheap, can be located online and above all: self sufficient. Wait what? Yes: these bikes make their own money. Nobody owns them.
This radical new approach of agency in products stems from the work of Simone Rebaudengo (automato.farm). Now The Incredible Machine and Automato.farm are collaborating to develop a first practical application in the form of a self-letting bicycles.
We need your input, ideas and knowledge to move ahead with this concept.
sessions.title: Infect the smart city with not so dumb bikes

sessions.description: The social, political and economic environment for living in the UK has changed dramatically for many over that year. The #brexit vote, conflict across Europe and a US election taking place a few days after the festival make this the perfect opportunity to sit down with a cup of tea, in the format of a traditional ‘salon’ (or the living room) and talk, debate, create a snapshot of the times.
sessions.title: Anybody Home?

sessions.description: The social, political and economic environment for living in the UK has changed dramatically for many over that year. The #brexit vote, conflict across Europe and a US election taking place a few days after the festival make this the perfect opportunity to sit down with a cup of tea, in the format of a traditional ‘salon’ (or the living room) and talk, debate, create a snapshot of the times.
sessions.title: Anybody Home?

sessions.description: This workshop will encourage participants to design interventions for increasingly gentrified, private, guarded, and surveilled spaces, in urban, suburban, and rural environments. Climate change, increasing wealth and privilege gaps, increased surveillance, and other strains are pulling residents of urban and rural environments even further apart than they were before -- even in the face of global communications technology. How can we bridge the gap? How can we share experiences by sharing challenges?
sessions.title: Town and Country

sessions.description:
IoT will significantly amplify the security and privacy challenges we currently face. One reason for this is because IoT brings computing power much closer to us physically and more pervasive. There are already examples of how this physical proximity and digital control of physical resources can result in life-threatening scenarios, such as a car being hacked or a pacemaker compromised.

IoT also collects more and different data than previous eras of the internet. This includes our physical location, appearance, and even emotional state.

As we build meaningful connected things, we must ensure that these objects don’t compromise people’s agency. People must be able to understand and control their digital lives. And control depends on context. We want to understand how designing for specific contexts can inform privacy best practices broadly.
sessions.title: Trust in IoT: An Insights Toolkit for designers

sessions.description: This session will explore how we can make the impact of political decisions and social issues more tangible in people’s everyday lives. How can we use the physical interfaces people encounter and use most often - from smartphones to bus shelters - to reach out to an increasingly disengaged populace, directly showing them the impact not just of their local political representatives but their own choices as well. Although we often see the impact of cuts in spending or shutting down public services, it is often at a point that’s too late to do anything about - perhaps there is a way, through accessible interactive data visualisations, audio-visual projections, haptic enabled interfaces that can help us all better connect the dots.
sessions.title: Pervasive Computing as a tool for Social Justice

sessions.description:
We take directions from our phones. On the web, helpful algorithms suggest what we should buy, where we should eat, who we should be friends with, which news articles are worth our time. In the wider world, they have been trading in the stock market, advising on prison sentences, and even deciding which Hollywood films should be made.
This session will explore our relationships with algorithms, as servants, advisors and scapegoats. We'll explore the need for careful design and transparency, as well as the need to retain some control.
sessions.title: My best friend's a flowchart

sessions.description: Face paint is a staple of festivals everywhere. In this version, we'll use patterns and shapes that obscure our features from facial recognition.
sessions.title: Anti-Surveillance Face Paint

sessions.description: With smart TVs coming down in price and more IoT processors having HDMI output it has become easy to get Web browsers on big screens.  We want to enable people to do this with their own home screens and participate in growing what the Web is capable of.
sessions.title: As seen on TV!!

sessions.description: With smart TVs coming down in price and more IoT processors having HDMI output it has become easy to get Web browsers on big screens.  We want to enable people to do this with their own home screens and participate in growing what the Web is capable of.
sessions.title: As seen on TV!!

sessions.description: With smart TVs coming down in price and more IoT processors having HDMI output it has become easy to get Web browsers on big screens.  We want to enable people to do this with their own home screens and participate in growing what the Web is capable of.
sessions.title: As seen on TV!!

sessions.description: With smart TVs coming down in price and more IoT processors having HDMI output it has become easy to get Web browsers on big screens.  We want to enable people to do this with their own home screens and participate in growing what the Web is capable of.
sessions.title: As seen on TV!!

sessions.description: Infect festival goers with as many ideas as possible by getting them to every space on every floor.
sessions.title: WARNING, MOZFEST INFECTED WITH VIRULENT IDEA OUTBREAK!

sessions.description:
Welcome, tired festival nomads!

Come chill and hack quietly by the fire in the nomadic encampment. Lay back and work on a project that inspired you, or write up some thoughts you had during your festival experience, or just sit and enjoy the flickering lights of the digital artworks being projected from the fire.
sessions.title: Nomad Tent Oasis

sessions.description:
Welcome, tired festival nomads!

Come chill and hack quietly by the fire in the nomadic encampment. Lay back and work on a project that inspired you, or write up some thoughts you had during your festival experience, or just sit and enjoy the flickering lights of the digital artworks being projected from the fire.
sessions.title: Nomad Tent Oasis

sessions.description:
Welcome, tired festival nomads!

Come chill and hack quietly by the fire in the nomadic encampment. Lay back and work on a project that inspired you, or write up some thoughts you had during your festival experience, or just sit and enjoy the flickering lights of the digital artworks being projected from the fire.
sessions.title: Nomad Tent Oasis

sessions.description:
Welcome, tired festival nomads!

Come chill and hack quietly by the fire in the nomadic encampment. Lay back and work on a project that inspired you, or write up some thoughts you had during your festival experience, or just sit and enjoy the flickering lights of the digital artworks being projected from the fire.
sessions.title: Nomad Tent Oasis

sessions.description: This is a facilitated small space, designed to look like part of a living room, which uses Design Fiction props to get people to think about what they want from the TV of the future. We use attractive objects (fake packaging, instructions), printouts (hopefully in the form of glossy magazines), and a video to describe possible directions for TV. These are designed to make the future objects feel real, so people can make informed decisions about tradeoffs between privacy and convenience, and filtered content and the difficulties of choice. We may have some semi-working physical devices too.
sessions.title: What would TV be like if it were….?

sessions.description: The social, political and economic environment for living in the UK has changed dramatically for many over that year. The #brexit vote, conflict across Europe and a US election taking place a few days after the festival make this the perfect opportunity to sit down with a cup of tea, in the format of a traditional ‘salon’ (or the living room) and talk, debate, create a snapshot of the times.
sessions.title: Living in the UK post Brexit

sessions.description:
The ThingsCon community fosters the creation of a human-centric and responsible Internet of Things (IoT). We want to support consumer rights organizations like EFF and Consumer Reports in this area. Help us draft materials that can help these organizations navigate the challenges surrounding IoT.
After a quick intro to the state of affairs in consumer rights and IoT, we'll have a group discussion of the major pitfalls and opportunities for consumer rights groups in that area.
sessions.title: ThingsCon: Responsible IoT for Consumer Rights Orgs

sessions.description:
Build flags that are a mashup of where attendees come from, showing that 'home', place of birth and origins aren't the same thing.
We'll be making new fiction flags that represent our current homes from paper.
sessions.localized description: Les personnes parlant français sont les bienvenues à cette présentation.
sessions.title: Flag-o-ra-ma

sessions.description:
Interview (in person or via Skype) about art & migration, with TBC guests
How does migration and Brexit shape art, how can art explore complex issues like migration and Brexit?
This is for anyone with an interest in art and/or politics and migration.
sessions.title: Framing migration

sessions.description:
Talk about families in a global sense and discuss objects we take with us, rituals we carry with us from the ‘mother land’ how we take home away from home.
Draw those objects, make a paper quilt out of it that we exhibit throughout the weekend.
This is for anyone interested in global migration, a connected to home, and how objects carry and shape what "home" means for us.
sessions.title: Motherland objects / Tea time

sessions.description:
Exhibition opening of all the things made throughout the day at the Good Home space.
We'll give a little introduction to the Good Home and the exhibitions on display and close the day with some drinks.
For anyone interested in better living in the 21 century, connected homes, migratory living, technologists, designers.
sessions.title: Closing drinks & exhibition

sessions.description:
"Papers, please!" is an award winning serious game by Lucas Pope set in a fictional 1980s Eastern Bloc country. It explores the absurdities that shape migration experiences, and the hidden agendas and dilemmas that influence decision making at border control. The game will be available for self-directed play throughout the weekend.

Playing this game makes you think about the decision making and ethical dilemmas that a border guard might face while deciding about the fate of migrations. We recommend playing this in small groups of 2-3.

This is a game for all ages, but we recommend having an adult in the group to provide some context and explanations.
sessions.title: PAPERS, PLEASE

sessions.description:
Pegmodular is a kit which allows low-income, transient homemakers the opportunity to live with interesting, adaptable and affordable furniture.
This exhibit explores low-cost, flexible furniture and furthermore shows that even the youngest among us have valuable contributions to make to this conversation: The artist is only 16 years old.
sessions.title: Pegmodular

sessions.description:
Cloud Index is a series of simulations: a weather forecast for possible futures. The simulations depict proposed cloud structures which correspond to measured electoral scenarios. These are dreams of the weather, hallucinated by machines. If we wish to change the future, we must change the weather. First: a binary choice. To leave, or to remain. Cloud Index is commissioned by Serpentine Galleries.

For Technologists, citizens, anyone with an interest in politics as well as the shaping powers of technology.
sessions.title: Cloud Index

sessions.description:
A physical brick that helps you manage your home data and your city services to connect to you in a better way.

Your home has a deep shadow of data, it is not just the physical materials that make the walls, floors, ceiling, the pipes and wires that provide the services, there is information on the construction, how it sits in the physical landscape, where it sits in the legal landscape. A whole lot of information goes into a home and a whole lot more just keeps coming out of it. Data Brick explores how we can navigate and control this kind of data in the future.
sessions.title: Data Brick

sessions.description:
Teleport Machine allows migrants to switch their IP addresses to a location of their choice, enabling them to connect to local online content in their home countries, like connecting to the BBC from abroad. Teleport Machines is part of a Privacy Machines, a family of experimental devices that explore better and easier way of controlling privacy levels in a connected home. Created in a collaboration with Mozilla Open IoT Studio. Collaborators also include Vladan Joler and Rachel Uwa.

Teleport Machine helps explore what it means to live abroad through banal, day-to-day interactions like trying to watch the newscasts and pop culture you grew up with.
sessions.title: Teleport Machine (Privacy Machines Part III)

sessions.description: Put on the headset and let your creative spirit loose in an infinite and unconstrained space, expressing yourself visually with A-Painter, a virtual reality painting experience delivered through WebVR.
sessions.title: Painting with Virtual Reality and A-Painter

sessions.description: Put on the headset and let your creative spirit loose in an infinite and unconstrained space, expressing yourself visually with A-Painter, a virtual reality painting experience delivered through WebVR.
sessions.title: Painting with Virtual Reality and A-Painter

sessions.description: Put on the headset and let your creative spirit loose in an infinite and unconstrained space, expressing yourself visually with A-Painter, a virtual reality painting experience delivered through WebVR.
sessions.title: Painting with Virtual Reality and A-Painter

sessions.description: Put on the headset and let your creative spirit loose in an infinite and unconstrained space, expressing yourself visually with A-Painter, a virtual reality painting experience delivered through WebVR.
sessions.title: Painting with Virtual Reality and A-Painter

sessions.description: The Databox - www.databoxproject.uk - provides a radical alternative to widespread data harvesting and data processing ‘in the cloud’. Instead data processing takes place ‘on the box’ and is limited to what is needed to deliver specific services. We introduce the Databox platform to the Mozilla community and provide participants with the opportunity to get their hands on this novel privacy-preserving platform.
sessions.title: Databox

This hands on session will exploit data provided by Internet of Things devices deployed around the Mozilla Festival.
sessions.title: Databox: Hack an App (hack on)

sessions.description: This is a quiet hack following the previous hack a Databox session - www.databoxproject.uk - Introducing the Databox platform to the Mozilla community and provide participants with the opportunity to get their hands on this novel privacy-preserving platform. This hands on session will exploit data provided by Internet of Things devices deployed around the Mozilla Festival.
sessions.title: Databox: Hack an App (hack on)

sessions.description:
Activity - engaging citizen scientists and analytics experts:
Attendees will be taught the basic principles of Human Centric Lighting and how the body’s organ functions are directly linked to the rise and fall of the sun. From NASA to horticulturists, light is increasingly recognised as a drug for living organisms. If used correctly, light can improve sleep as well as focus.
Experiment with Smart Diffuser and experience the effects of the light:
Based on research carried out in classrooms, offices and even on the International Space Station, attendees will be able to program a set of Quantum Dot enhanced lights (the Smart Diffuser TM) to shift colour temperature over a 10 minute period and find out the effect on their body. Nano-Lit will stream the data collected in real time to an online server to see if results are valuable and what they tell us about Human Centric Lighting.
sessions.title: Is Light a Supplement?

sessions.description: The reality of innovation in 2016 is that the best ideas can come from anywhere.  We will review ideas from Saturday.  Session open to everyone, not just participants from Saturday.
sessions.title: Open Innovators - review

sessions.description: Toys began as homemade things, often made by children themselves to designs passed down through generations.  The growth of the maker community, the capacity of the Internet to share ideas and the delight of a successful make, 3D printing, and more, should enable a resurgence of delightful, quirky, cheap, amazing, personal, empowering, life changing TOYS!  Let's make some!
sessions.title: Back to the - Future toys

sessions.description: IoT will significantly amplify the security and privacy challenges we currently face. Let's identify gaps in knowledge about UX + privacy among practitioners creating meaningful connected things. This sessions using an interact card kit to prioritize areas of interest, and identify ways to to support the developer community to consider trust issues in IoT.
sessions.title: Trust in IoT: An Insights Toolkit for developers

sessions.description: What are the professional practices and templates we should use to foster open IoT? This session will begin to scope what resources exist, where there might be gaps, and how we can develop this workbench in the open so that more practitioners can benefit from and contribute to new and dilerate ways of making responsible IoT.
sessions.title: Open ioT Workbench I

sessions.description:
How can locally relevant and locally produced IoT contribute to more resilient systems? Currently, several large corporate players are shaping IoT. Their power is quite centralised, even though they compete against each other. Centralised power means there is a single point of failure. And it means that individual agency is limited, especially at the edges of a network.

For this reason, we are committed to making meaningful things in local contexts. Open innovation at the edges can shift centralised power, leading to products that are locally relevant and adapted. We are particularly interested in exploring the contexts of decentralization that can empower communities to be more resilient through making locally relevant IoT.
sessions.title: Decentralisation and community resilience

sessions.description: Continued: What are the professional practices and templates we should use to foster open IoT? This session will begin to scope what resources exist, where there might be gaps, and how we can develop this workbench in the open so that more practitioners can benefit from and contribute to new and dilerate ways of making responsible IoT.
sessions.title: Open ioT Workbench II

sessions.description: Let's reflect on the weekend and discuss what we can do next as a network. The time is right to not only ask what is possible for IoT, but what is responsible. We're learning how to embed internet health in the making of meaningful connected things. We're looking at issues like privacy & security, decentralization and open innovation in IoT. Join IoT professionals working in the field alongside local communities to produce research, prototypes and best practices that demonstrate how Mozilla's principles can be implemented in connected products.
sessions.title: Where next for the Open IoT Studio!

sessions.description: 90% of IoT is being manufactured in Shenzhen. Come to our electronics market to learn more about what you can hack, build and ship in this unique, open ecosystem.
sessions.title: Shenzhen Open Hardware Market

sessions.description:
How can locally relevant and locally produced IoT contribute to more resilient systems? Currently, several large corporate players are shaping IoT. Their power is quite centralised, even though they compete against each other. Centralised power means there is a single point of failure. And it means that individual agency is limited, especially at the edges of a network.

For this reason, we are committed to making meaningful things in local contexts. Open innovation at the edges can shift centralised power, leading to products that are locally relevant and adapted. We are particularly interested in exploring the contexts of decentralization that can empower communities to be more resilient through making locally relevant IoT.
sessions.title: Decentralisation and community resilience

sessions.description: Did you know making a meme technically isn't allowed in many parts of the EU? And that it’s illegal to share a picture of the Eiffel Tower light display at night? Did you know in some parts of the EU, teachers aren’t legally allowed to screen films or share teaching materials in the classroom? Think that’s absurd? So do we and we've assembled a panel of experts to talk about what's wrong and what you can do. Come hear from friends at Creative Commons, Communia, Copyright 4 Creativity, European Digital Rights, the International Federation of Library Associations, and Mozilla. This session will set the stage so you can stand up for copyright reform across Europe.
sessions.localized description: Les personnes parlant français sont les bienvenues à cette présentation.
sessions.title: Reform EU Copyright: What's Wrong With It, and What You Can Do

sessions.description: What does it mean for a movement to "win"? Drawing from 350.org's lessons in the climate movement and on the knowledge of participants in the session, we'll be exploring together what kind of organising and campaigning it takes to build a broader and more powerful open internet movement – a movement that wins.
sessions.title: Building the Open Internet Movement -- Stages + Strategies

sessions.description: Chances are that, when it comes to advocacy campaigns, you have access to more data than you know what to do with. Mozilla’s Copyright Campaign has engaged tens of thousand of people across the EU in the last few months. If you are wondering where the most/least engaged supporters or how the campaign message resonates with different cultures across the continent, this is the session for you. Come explore, analyze and brainstorm ideas around key metrics and learn how to activate insights in your vast datasets.
sessions.title: Got Data? Now let's activate it!

sessions.description: What's in store for net neutrality in 2017 and 2018? Let's do some ecosystem mapping to strategize around partnerships and outreach for effective net neutrality coalition work.
sessions.title: What's Next for NN in the EU after BEREC?

sessions.description: Two German artists walked into the Neues Museum in central Berlin in October and used a mobile device to secretly scan the 19-inch-tall bust of Queen Nefertiti, a limestone-and-stucco sculpture more than 3,000 years old that is one of Germany’s most visited attractions. They used the data to create copies of the bust and delivered them to Egypt. But who really owns art and culture? Come talk to Nora and Nikolai, two innovative open-culture enthusiasts who are using technology to expose the weaknesses in arguments of copyright and arts ownership.
sessions.title: Nefertiti Hack

sessions.description: Two German artists walked into the Neues Museum in central Berlin in October and used a mobile device to secretly scan the 19-inch-tall bust of Queen Nefertiti, a limestone-and-stucco sculpture more than 3,000 years old that is one of Germany’s most visited attractions. They used the data to create copies of the bust and delivered them to Egypt. But who really owns art and culture? Come talk to Nora and Nikolai, two innovative open-culture enthusiasts who are using technology to expose the weaknesses in arguments of copyright and arts ownership.
sessions.title: Nefertiti Hack

Come talk to Nora and Nikolai, two innovative open-culture enthusiasts who are using technology to expose the weaknesses in arguments of copyright and arts ownership.
sessions.title: Nefertiti Hack

Come talk to Nora and Nikolai, two innovative open-culture enthusiasts who are using technology to expose the weaknesses in arguments of copyright and arts ownership.
sessions.title: Nefertiti Hack

sessions.description: How can we use patents to foster innovation? How do patents impact all of us on a daily basis? Let's explore what's possible and impossible to do with Free/Libre Open Source (FLOS) and Open Hardware (OH) licences. We'll talk about the current obstacles/challenges that patents present to open software and open hardware, how patents can expressly permit everyone to openly innovate, and how open source patents can prevent patent trolls or proprietary entities from claiming technologies that are meant for everyone. The more entities that license their software patents to include and encourage open innovation (rather than reserve all rights to exclude) the healthier the open source ecosystem gets.
sessions.title: Patents for Innovation

sessions.description: Come learn about the slew of laws in the US that chill speech and activity around tinkering and innovation. Users should have the freedom to innovate, but some laws make this impossible. What laws make reverse engineering illegal? What's being done about it? How can you take part and join the fight to reform these laws?
sessions.title: Protecting the Freedom to Innovate - Hacking Law in the US

sessions.description: What if our favorite storybook heroes had to deal with patents? Find out by playing PatentQuest and to learn about the challenges and opportunities that Intellectual Property (patents, copyright, etc.) present to open source software and the Web.
sessions.title: It's dangerous to go alone! - The PatentQuest game

sessions.description: What does it mean to be a good leader? How do you share responsibility and delegate? Delegation is important because it helps to prevent burnout, develops skills in others, and generates a culture of enthusiasm, innovation, creativity, cooperation, and openness. Come share your stories and discuss barriers to delegating, how to overcome them, and how to give good feedback to others.
sessions.title: Organizing for Action: Sharing Responsibility

sessions.description: What are the main failures in existing EU copyright law? Are there some best case scenarios? Let's talk about exceptions and limitations, copyright enforcement, geo-blocking and other topics from an open web perspective. Copyright affects everyone in different ways and how this is not a matter of "rights holders vs pirates".

2.affiliated org: OMMUNIA Association for the Digital Public Domain
2.name: Teresa Nobre

sessions.title: #CopyFails and Best-Case Scenarios for Copyright

sessions.description: This session is an original simulation of the European Union's decision-making process. The battlefield: The upcoming copyright reform and proposal to censor links on the web (so-called "link tax"). This session will give you a unique opportunity to a. get first-hand experience of the functioning of European institutions, b. find out how to get engaged and c. learn how to talk to policy-makers about the copyright reform.
sessions.title: Bursting the EU bubble: What you can do to save the link!

sessions.description: How can everyday users of the internet get personalized and research-based recommendations to improve their digital security? What makes security education empowering and motivational? Citizen Lab is attempting to tackle these challenges with Security Planner, an online, interactive survey that provides easy-to-use security advice personalized to a user's technology platforms and risk factors. Help us improve Security Planner by providing feedback how we can adapt the tool and its recommendations to better meet your needs and those of the communities you work with.
sessions.title: Research-Based Digital Security Advice for Everyday Internet Users

sessions.description: Global rights campaigners are finding it harder and harder to engage communities in the most pressing fights of our time: climate change, LGBT rights, immigrant rights, digital rights, and more. Tactics and strategies that worked in the past are no longer resonating. How can we learn from past challenges to redefine strategies for engaging millions of people online? How do we define success? Let's share best practices and collaborate on 2017 strategies; let's work together over the next 6 months and share our learning at events like RightsCon next year.
sessions.title: How to Engage Activists in 2017

sessions.description: WebExtensions let you hack and "remix" your web browser in many ways, such as alter content from any website, augment the toolbar, manage windows and tabs, intercept network requests, and much more. Join us for a hands on workshop where we will build our own WebExtensions after a quick introduction to the tools and concepts. WebExtensions are zipped folders comprised of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. With today’s WebExtension API, it’s possible to create a single extension that will run in Firefox, Chrome, and Opera. No advanced knowledge of WebExtensions is required but experience building a standard web page is recommended.
sessions.title: Hack and Remix the Web with Web Extensions

sessions.description: How do you get people engaged with your cause? Come practice translating important (but potentially boring) messages into something exciting and emotional. Remember, less is always more!
sessions.title: Everything in Life is about the TL;DR

sessions.description: What motivates people to get engaged? User-centered design can help you find out. An approach traditonally used by software/tech designers, it can help you view social change issues from the perspective of the stakeholder. Come find out how to use this tool to strengthen your campaign.
sessions.title: Hacking User Centred Design for Social Change

sessions.description: How do you learn from your mistakes? Activists around the globe share similar struggles and we can learn from each others' mistakes. Conferences alway show the best of the best, but failures can be as important as successes. In this session we'll explore ways to constructively talk about and learn from failures. Come listen to others and share your learnings and the strategies to turn failure into success. Outcomes are to start sharing our failures in the open in order to keep an honest community and to stop making the same mistakes.
sessions.title: Failing Forward

sessions.description: What if we could create a shared set of open source engagement tools? Copyright and other key digital policy battles require ongoing online engagement tools from organizations that are often under-resourced or don’t have all the technical tools they need. The digital rights campaign platform - from NewMode, in collaboration with OpenMedia and other open Internet advocates - will provide advocates with affordable access to advanced online advocacy tools. The platform will make use of OpenMedia’s tested stack of engagement tools, which have already been used in some of the world’s largest open Internet campaigns.
sessions.title: Building a Shared Platform for Digital Rights Campaigners

sessions.description: What are some ways to combat restrictive copyright measures and government censorship? Can we do it  through defending the hyperlink? We’ll introduce our interactive map that identifies threats to the hyperlink around the world, and highlights actions users can take to defend it. Let's crowdsource threats from Internet users, build this map to be an educational resource, and defend the hyperlink worldwide.
sessions.title: Save The Link: Threats Map Project

sessions.description: Come by anytime to get creative and make your own activist art!  We'll have a variety of supplies and laser cut stencils so you can make your own buttons/pins, t-shirts, and picket signs or add activist art to your MozFest art. We'll also have an area for activist art selfies.
sessions.title: Making Change: DIY Activist Art

sessions.description: How would you discover locally relevant content? Let's brainstorm ideas -- maybe even build a prototype -- on how to surface locally relevant content through some sort of tech tool. A session for designers, developers, and enthusiasts who care about localization, native content, and creating a web that's relevant to you, wherever you are.
sessions.title: Discovering Local Content: What tech tools can we build?

sessions.description: Movements multiply their chances of success when they can draw upon each other’s best strategic insights and creative approaches — which is precisely the role that the Beautiful Rising toolbox plays. We invite you for a test of what it can do, and how you can become part of serving it back to the movements where it belongs. Come play our free game and take it home with you!
sessions.title: Beautiful Rising - A Campaign Strategy Card Game

sessions.description:
Do you understand your rights? Digital media can obfuscate copyright understanding. The intangibility of exchanging images, videos, audio clips and data in the form of vines, ebooks, music streaming and so on means that it can be hard for consumers to know their rights in regard to intellectual property. This is often exploited by organisations who rely on intellectual property as part of their business model. An important part of copyright reform is not only a reassessment of the legal rights of consumers, but also a reassessment of how rights are communicated and how consumers are made tangibly aware of their rights in their interactions.

Additional Facilitators:
Justin Pickard - Strange Telemetry
sessions.title: Copyright Interventions

sessions.description: Advocacy work is not immune from the challenges of classism, racism and sexism. In fact sometimes our work to do social good can obscure the problems and conflicts that arise internally and allows for implicit bias to occur. These issues can be opportunities to change “business as usual” by identifying problems and addressing gender/racial equity in our workplaces or activist communities. During this session we will discuss the challenges or barriers to equity and together craft solutions. For those interested in staying connected after the workshop, we will create a slack channel for ongoing peer support.
sessions.title: Chill Bro: Let's Build Diverse and Equitable Teams

sessions.description: In advocacy work, it’s not rare for staff and volunteer to experience harassment as a result of their exposure. During MozFest, we’d like to convene a group of professionals to discuss what sorts of actions and policies are needed to provide support for staff and volunteers who experience this sort of harassment. We’d like to walk out of MozFest with a shareable document with these best-practices and concrete next steps to enact these policies for other organizations.
sessions.title: Supporting Staff and Volunteers Who Experience Online Harassment: Best-Practices

sessions.description: Education affects all of us - lifelong learning education is a standard, we all develop, progress and discover new things using various learning methods - the age doesn’t matter. Therefore copyright policy needs to empower – and not thwart – the activities of teaching and learning. What changes should be introduced to make copyright framework more flexible and future-proof considering educational practices? What are pioneers in education doing, and how do the copyright rules enable or hold back these innovative (open) education practices? Come discuss and build an infographic to address these and other questions!
sessions.title: Keep Copyright Out of the Classroom

sessions.description: What Revolution? is the first in a series of images challenging the ideas of celebrity and idols. The 1960 photograph of Che Guevara by Alberto Korda has been endlessly mutated, transformed, and morphed. It can be found advertising anything from belts and “hip and cool” t-shirts to health insurance. It is tacked onto political movements without much consideration of the history behind it. One has to ask if his image is still the symbol for change and revolution that it was fifty years ago, when it was furiously distributed throughout Europe by Jim Fitzpatrick in protest of the conditions of Guevera’s murder.
sessions.title: What Revolution?

sessions.description: What Revolution? is the first in a series of images challenging the ideas of celebrity and idols. sessions.description: Three short videos from writer-director Marisa Zanotti, choreographer Lea Anderson, and composer Matthew Whiteside that remix content to share pointed, political and social messages.
sessions.title: Glamour, Salvage and Reconstruction

sessions.title: Glamour, Salvage and Reconstruction

sessions.description: There are hundreds of mass and digital surveillance companies popping up around the world. This relatively unregulated cottage industry is booming, while we have our rights eroded. We want to get everyday people talking about it, so we're hosting a massive wikipedia edit-a-thon. Come meet veteran wikipedia editors, Mozilla Open Web Fellows, and experts in the field. Help us create articles and link to news stories containing information about IMSI catchers, Modem Sniffers, Malware, and encryption downgrading technologies. We need people to translate pages, update articles, link to citations and references, and disseminate this knowledge to journalists. We need help with file formats and copy writing, scripting, and media activism.
sessions.title: All Eyes on Surveillance

sessions.description: There are hundreds of mass and digital surveillance companies popping up around the world. This relatively unregulated cottage industry is booming, while we have our rights eroded. We want to get everyday people talking about it, so we're hosting a massive wikipedia edit-a-thon.
